unnormalised: Delhi's air quality is still a bit of a headache, folks. While things improved slightly after Diwali, recent data shows the Air Quality Index (AQI) is creeping back up in areas like Anand Vihar.
normalised: Delhi's air quality is still a bit of a headache, folks. While things improved slightly after Diwali, recent data shows the Air Quality Index (A Q I) is creeping back up in areas like Anand Vihar.

unnormalised: Dr. Sharma from the Central Pollution Control Board (CPCB) says cooler temperatures and less wind are to blame, trapping pollutants closer to the ground. It's not quite at "severe" levels yet, but enough to make your eyes water a little.
normalised: Doctor Sharma from the Central Pollution Control Board (C P C B) says cooler temperatures and less wind are to blame, trapping pollutants closer to the ground. It's not quite at "severe" levels yet, but enough to make your eyes water a little.

unnormalised: The government is considering implementing GRAP (Graded Response Action Plan) measures again, which could mean restrictions on construction activity and older vehicles. Think less dust, fewer trucks, and maybe even dusting off those air purifiers at home.
normalised: The government is considering implementing G R A P (Graded Response Action Plan) measures again, which could mean restrictions on construction activity and older vehicles. Think less dust, fewer trucks, and maybe even dusting off those air purifiers at home.

unnormalised: Remember that 'nani ke nuskhe' of tulsi and honey for that scratchy throat! Plus, planting more trees, especially indigenous species like neem, can really help long term. Imagine a greener Delhi, one tree at a time. Experts say even a few more green patches of 1000 sq ft each can make a difference. Let's hope things clear up soon. Rs. 500 fine for open burning is also in effect, so be mindful! And remember, walking even a short distance near busy roads exposes you to high pollution, so mask up!
normalised: Remember that 'nani ke nuskhe' of tulsi and honey for that scratchy throat! Plus, planting more trees, especially indigenous species like neem, can really help long term. Imagine a greener Delhi, one tree at a time. Experts say even a few more green patches of one thousand square feet each can make a difference. Let's hope things clear up soon. Rupee five hundred fine for open burning is also in effect, so be mindful! And remember, walking even a short distance near busy roads exposes you to high pollution, so mask up!
